repnme.cdata!:
Trinidad and Tobago - Business Expansion
            and Industrial Restructuring Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            unsatisfactory, and sustainability is uncertain. The
            confluence of several factors, namely, an overly ambitious
            project design, lack of institutional capacity and staff
            continuity, coupled with weak decision-making, affected the
            project outcome. The lessons convey that complex, and
            difficult privatization projects, are further menaced by the
            unpredictable interplay of several economic forces, thus the
            inclusion of monitoring indicators and impact evaluation,
            would facilitate periodic reviews on relevant project
            interventions, and allow compliance with a clearly defined
            project design. Furthermore, periodic reviews should be
            supplemented by personal, detailed insights from the
            concerned minister, to convey accountability, and, speed
            significant actions if problems, or delays occur. The
            administration of the project was particularly affected by
            the lack of capacity, and instruments to support project
            management, therefore it is suggested that Special Accounts
            be used only when internal control procedures are in place
            in the project management unit, and ensure that documented
            reconciliations be made prior to requested replenishments,
            secured by strong financial management, and accounting
            practices. The sensitivity of key project positions,
            requires a joint agreed decision prior to appraisal, between
            the Bank, and the Government.

5082167.trustfund:
TF035480-TRINIDAD & TOBAGO -
            BUSINESS EXPANSION & INDUSTRIAL RESTRUCTURING,TF022214-CANADIAN GENERAL CTF II-CARIBBEAN,TF023450-CANADIAN CONSULTANT TF FOR ENVIRONMENT,TF035941-TRINIDAD & TOBAGO - REVIEW

5082167.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Trinidad and Tobago - Business Expansion
            and Industrial Restructuring Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project promotes development and/or
            restructuring of private manufacturing or service firms,
            especially in entering and competing in export markets.  The
            project includes components for productive sector credit and
            technical assistance.  The credit component will help
            private enterprises finance a wide range of investments,
            including plant and equipment, incremental working capital,
            and technical services related to development of productive
            activities within a liberalized incentive regime.  Technical
            assistance will be provided to:  (a) establish an export
            technical assistance facility to assist private
            manufacturing and service firms to enter extra-CARICOM
            markets; (b) enable the Trinidad and Tobago Bureau of
            Standards and the Caribbean Industrial Research Institute to
            provide industry with internationally-recognized industrial
            standards, quality management, metrology, and testing
            services; (c) develop improved environmental pollution
            control standards for evaluating investment proposals, and
            strenghten the Town and Country Planning Division's
            capacity to review environmental impact assessments; and (d)
            finance studies to build the government's understanding
            of the organizational and ownership options and review the
            effectiveness of new foreign investment regime; and (e)
            assist the Ministry of Finance to strengthen the regulatory
            framework for the insurance industry.
